awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:An IoT Smart Shower for Hotel Utility Savings
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to save over $50 billion in building utility costs annually across the U.S. by saving 200 billion gallons of water and 1 trillion kWh of energy. Reducing the overall water and energy demand decreases the strain on municipal infrastructure. The proposed project consists of a highly accurate method to generate valuable utility end-user behavior data in hot, humid environments.  Public and private organizations can use the data to design better policies and best practices. Moreover, the occupancy detection technology can be used for other applications where difficult ambient conditions prevent the use of conventional sensors. In addition to the economic and environmental benefits to the user, the business will create engineering, sales, and customer support jobs. 

The proposed project will eliminate behavioral water waste occurring when a bather leaves a shower unoccupied even after water warm-up.  Project objectives include development of: (1) a device that can accurately sense shower occupancy across multiple shower/bathtub layouts; (2) a low energy circuit and algorithm for long battery life; and (3) systems engineering of a designed enclosure resilient to a shower's hot and humid environment.  Project tasks include signal analysis for sensor accuracy, in-situ pilot testing across all rooms of multiple buildings, industrial design and accelerated aging tests. Technical milestones include: (1) Design a sensor that detects human presence within a 1% error margin when tested across at least 25 different hotel bathtub/shower layouts, (2) Complete live user-sponsored pilot tests in the rooms of at least 3 hotels for at least 1 year, and (3) Demonstrate that the amount of shower water and energy saved is at least 20% when compared to the baseline.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF SBIR Phase II Outcomes Report

Overview

Abstract Engineering Inc has developed a new IoT product called Shower Stream and introduced it to the hotel market. This product saves hotel owners and operators over 20% in shower utility costs, and will increase U.S water resiliency by eliminating billions of gallons of hot water waste every year.

The fundamental problem that Shower Stream addresses is called Shower Behavioral Warm-up Waste. Lawrence Berkeley National Labs show that 70% of bathers leave their showers unattended and 52% of bathers multitask while their shower warms up. This leaves their showers to run unoccupied long after the water is warm, almost 2 minutes on average, for every shower in the US. Common examples of multitasking behaviors while the shower warms up include brushing one's teeth, using the bathroom or shaving.

Shower Stream is a shower head which contains a motion-sensitive valve that stays open to allow the water to warm-up then closes to stop waste water flow if the bather has not yet entered the shower. The occupancy sensor detects when the bather enters the shower and resumes the flow of water automatically. Absolutely no change to guest shower behavior is required since the water only stops when the guest is not in the shower. Furthermore, the Shower Stream shower head is a luxury rainfall showerhead which represents a massive guest satisfaction upgrade for economy hotels. The hardware device has a temperature sensor to record and monitor shower temperature, and a wifi adapter to connect with the Shower Stream analytics software in the cloud.  

Intellectual Merit

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project produced a breakthrough in IoT sensor technology. A novel human presence detector was developed during phase I research which shows 99% accuracy in a lab setting. The sensor is very small, low-cost, low-power and can be embedded inside any electronic enclosure. 

During this Phase II effort, Shower Stream's hotel utility savings, sensor compatibility and industrial design were validated by successfully achieving the following key technical objectives:

 

  • A universally compatible sensor array was developed that detects human occupancy within at most a 1% error margin when tested across multiple hotel bathrooms.
  • A live 1 year hotel pilot test demonstrated that the amount of shower water and energy saved was at least 20% when compared to baseline.
  • An industrial product design was developed that resulted in at least 80% positive reviews, according to at least 50 customer interviews. This demonstrated that hotel guests prefer the Shower Stream shower head over the status quo economy hotel shower head.

 

Commercialization 

The Shower Stream shower head is free to install and the product’s monthly utility savings exceeds its monthly fee. This nets hotel operators an immediate, recurring and risk-free reduction in OPEX while providing a high-quality rainfall shower head experience to improve guest satisfaction. As a result, the largest hotel operators in the U.S including Hyatt, Extended Stay America and Motel6 plus the U.S Department of Defense are among Shower Stream’s first customers. 

Abstract Engineering Inc has partnered with Sloan Faucets and Exelon Corporation to support its bathroom fixture product offering and validate its utility savings methodology with state public utility commissions. Additionally, Abstract Engineering Inc has attracted over $1.5M in venture capital to fund its operations. Shower Stream has generated over $800,000 of revenue in its first year of commercialization, and is working on scaling its operations to service over 250,000 of its customers’ hotel rooms.

Unexpected Results

Due to its unique access to disaggregated shower data from its novel IoT metering platform, Abstract Engineering Inc discovered 50% more behavioral shower waste than predicted by existing literature. The data clearly shows this extreme behavioral shower waste occurs among a small number of guests who waste a very large amount of shower water in a hotel setting. Common improper hotel shower uses which cause this extreme waste include: steaming clothes, room heat & humidification and improper garbage disposal. Abstract Engineering Inc published this novel discovery at the 2024 ACEEE Hot Water Forum.

Broader Impacts

Showering is one of the leading ways water is consumed in homes and buildings, accounting for nearly 17 percent of residential indoor water use, or about 30 gallons per household per day. Behavioral shower waste amounts to at least 200 billion gallons of water and at least 1 trillion kWh of energy wasted in the U.S. each year. The total cost of this waste is over $50 billion dollars every year in the U.S. alone. Other broad beneficial impacts include:

  • Providing municipalities with cost savings and reduced strain on water infrastructure.
  • Providing savings to hotels in order to increase their staff and reduce their costs.
  • Supporting national defense with more efficient showers for the U.S. DoD.
